user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.2 is: A project shall not contain dead code.
Any operation that is executed but whose removal would not affect program behaviour constitutes dead code. Notes:
1. The behaviour of an embedded sytem is often determined not just by the nature of its actions, but also by the time at which they occur.
2. unreachable code is not dead code, as it cannot be executed.
3.Initialization is not the same as an assignment operation and is therfore not a candidate for dead code.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of run_usock:
```c
static void *
run_usock (void *cls)
{
  struct MyData *md = cls;
  struct MHD_UpgradeResponseHandle *urh = md->urh;
  char buf[128];
  ssize_t got;

  make_blocking (md->sock);
  /* start by sending extra data MHD may have already read, if any */
  if (0 != md->extra_in_size)
  {
    send_all (md->sock,
              md->extra_in,
              md->extra_in_size);
    free (md->extra_in);
  }
  /* now echo in a loop */
  while (1)
  {
    got = recv (md->sock,
                buf,
                sizeof (buf),
                0);
    if (0 >= got)
      break;
    send_all (md->sock,
              buf,
              (size_t) got);
  }
  free (md);
  MHD_upgrade_action (urh,
                      MHD_UPGRADE_ACTION_CLOSE);
  return NULL;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: I have flagged all code fragments whose removal or behavior is not obviously required by the visible logic and therefore deserve investigation for potential dead-code violations under MISRA C 2023 Rule 2.2. Other fragments were not flagged because they are simple declarations, necessary assignments or control flow that are clearly used by the function and cannot be removed without changing behavior: - The local declarations (struct MyData *md = cls; struct MHD_UpgradeResponseHandle *urh = md->urh; char buf[128]; ssize_t got;) are initializations or variables used later (not candidates for dead code). - The recv call (got = recv(...)) and the loop control (if (0 >= got) break;) are active control-flow operations required to determine when to stop reading; they are not dead. - The send_all calls are included in the larger blocks flagged above; they have observable side effects (sending data) and so were considered for investigation only as parts of those blocks. - The final return NULL is the required thread-return value for this non-void function and cannot be removed without changing behavior/introducing undefined behavior. - No unreachable code (code that can never be executed) was detected in the snippet; the flagged fragments are potential instances where executed operations might be removable or redundant in the broader project context and therefore merit inspection.
